skill.name: dispatching-parallel-agents
skill.description: Use when facing 2+ independent tasks that can be worked on without shared state or sequential dependencies
skill.summary: Use when facing 2+ independent tasks that can be worked on without shared state or sequential depend...
skill.author: obra

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing markdown patterns for parallel agent dispatching. All 10 static findings are false positives: 7 from misidentified markdown code blocks, 1 from YAML frontmatter, 2 from benign workflow descriptions. No executable code exists in this skill.

content.user_title: Dispatch Parallel Agents for Independent Tasks
content.value_statement: Multiple independent failures waste time when investigated sequentially. This pattern dispatches one AI agent per independent problem domain, letting them work concurrently to solve separate issues in parallel.
actual_capabilities: Identifies independent problem domains in failing test suites
Creates focused agent tasks with specific scopes and clear goals
Dispatches multiple agents to work concurrently on separate issues
Provides structured review process for integrating parallel fixes
Defines agent prompt templates for effective problem isolation
limitations: Only works when failures are truly independent with no shared state
Does not execute code - provides workflow pattern and documentation
Requires human review to verify agent fixes do not conflict
Not suitable for exploratory debugging where scope is unknown

use_cases.title: Fix Multiple Test Failures
use_cases.description: Dispatch parallel agents to fix 3+ failing test files with different root causes concurrently.

use_cases.title: Debug Distributed Systems
use_cases.description: Investigate failures across multiple independent subsystems simultaneously without waiting on each other.

use_cases.title: Parallel Bug Investigation
use_cases.description: Send multiple agents to research different bugs in isolation while gathering context for each.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Parallel Dispatch
prompt_templates.prompt: Task one agent to fix file A failures. Task another to fix file B failures. Task a third to fix file C failures. All run concurrently.

prompt_templates.title: Independent Subsystems
prompt_templates.prompt: Agent 1: Fix authentication subsystem tests. Agent 2: Fix database subsystem tests. Agent 3: Fix API subsystem tests. No overlap in scope.

prompt_templates.title: Root Cause Isolation
prompt_templates.prompt: Agent 1: Investigate race condition in abort logic. Agent 2: Fix event structure bug in batch completion. Agent 3: Address async tool execution timing.

prompt_templates.title: Parallel Investigation
prompt_templates.prompt: Agent 1: Read and summarize failure patterns in file A. Agent 2: Read and summarize failure patterns in file B. Compare findings before deciding on fixes.

output_examples.input: We have 5 failing tests: 2 in agent-tool-abort.test.ts, 2 in batch-completion-behavior.test.ts, 1 in tool-approval-race-conditions.test.ts
output: Agent 1: Fixed abort timing issues by replacing arbitrary timeouts with event-based waiting
Agent 2: Fixed event structure bug (threadId in wrong place) in batch completion
Agent 3: Added wait for async tool execution to complete for race condition fix

output_examples.input: Three independent services are failing: auth-service tests, payment-service tests, and notification-service tests
output: Auth-service agent: Fixed token validation timing issue
Payment-service agent: Fixed transaction rollback logic
Notification-service agent: Fixed message queue handling
All fixes verified - full test suite green

output_examples.input: API tests failing in user-endpoint.test.ts and data-endpoint.test.ts with different error patterns
output: User-endpoint agent: Fixed missing user_id field in response schema
Data-endpoint agent: Fixed pagination offset calculation
Integration successful - no conflicts between changes

best_practices: Group failures by problem domain before dispatching - ensure each agent has independent scope
Provide specific test names, error messages, and file paths in each agent prompt
Add clear constraints: do not change production code, do not modify files outside assigned scope
Require each agent to return summary of root cause and specific changes made
anti_patterns: Sending all agents to fix everything - focused scope is essential for parallel effectiveness
Skipping context provision - agents need error messages and relevant code locations
Ignoring conflict review - agents might edit the same files or create conflicting changes
Using parallel dispatch for related failures - one agent should handle interconnected issues

faq.question: What makes failures independent?
faq.answer: Failures are independent when fixing one does not affect others. Different test files, different subsystems, no shared state between investigations.

faq.question: How many agents should I dispatch?
faq.answer: Dispatch one agent per independent problem domain. Start with 2-4 agents. More agents require more review overhead.

faq.question: What if agents edit the same files?
faq.answer: Review summaries carefully. Run full test suite after integration. If conflicts occur, resolve manually and consider narrower scoping.

faq.question: When should I NOT use this pattern?
faq.answer: Do not use when failures are related, need full system context, have shared state, or when scope of problems is unclear.

faq.question: Does this work with Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. Claude Code supports multiple concurrent Task calls. This pattern provides the structure for effective use of that capability.

faq.question: How do I verify agent fixes?
faq.answer: Read each summary, check for conflicting edits, run full test suite, and spot check key functionality. All fixes must work together.
